text.p: A group of 11 nearly century-old cars set off on Sunday to re-enact a landmark 1897 cross-country road trip that helped popularise a new mode of transportation in America -- the automobile.

Two of the cars were driven by great-grandsons of Alexander Winton, who made the 700-mile (1,130-km) trip from Cleveland, Ohio, to New York City over the rough roads of 100 years ago in an experimental motor car.
A crowd of several hundred car buffs, family members and the curious gathered on Cleveland's Public Square to cheer on participants in the commemorative journey, called "The Winton Centennial."
Winton, whose Cleveland company built most of the cars making the current trip, had hoped the long journey would prove to a sceptical public the reliability of the new form of transportation.
On July 28, 1897, he and his shop superintendent, William A. Hatcher, set out for New York, arriving on August 7 largely unnoticed after 78 hours and 43 minutes of driving.
Winton was disappointed by the continuing obscurity of motor transportation, but by March 1898 he completed what is considered to be the first car sale in the United States.

That year he sold 21 cars and eight delivery wagons. Winton continued to improve both his vehicles and his marketing, advertising in "Scientific American" and taking a second reliability run to New York in May 1899.

That drive took 47 hours and 34 minutes. As important as the shortened driving time was the presence of Charles B. Shanks, a reporter for the Cleveland Plain Dealer, who sent back reports that appeared in about 30 newspapers.

The publicity generated by the trip stimulated interest and sales in motor vehicles in the United States. Shanks' use of the French term "automobile" in his reports fixed that word in the American psyche.
The Winton company reached its peak in 1920, selling 2,500 cars. It stopped making vehicles in 1924, but a successor diesel engine-making company was bought by General Motors Corp. in 1930.

The commemorative trip is led by Charles F. Wake of Sarasota, Florida, and James A. Winton Jr., of Rocky River, Ohio, great grandsons of Alexander Winton. Wake is driving a 1899 Winton, and Winton is driving a 1916.
At the wheel of a 1921-vintage Winton is James R. Garfield, great-grandson of President James A. Garfield, who grew up in northeastern Ohio.
The commemorative journey also will include Wintons built in 1903, two 1904s, a 1906, 1907, and three 1912s. The oddball is a 1930s-era Chevrolet.
Wake, who posed for pictures in his leather driving helmet, goggles and long driving coat, said a Winton registry had located about 100 Wintons, most not drivable.
He spent six years planning the trip and getting the cars in running shape. "Many of these cars hadn't been driven in many years, so we had to update them," Winton said.
The updating won't speed the journey very much, which is expected to take seven days of eight-hours-a-day driving. Top speed of the 1897 model is about 20 mph (32 kph).
The group is expected to arrive in New York on June 22.
